exercise.title: 16 Compound Statements using P and Q

idx.h: 16 Compound Statements using P and Q

statement.p: The table below shows that are 16 possible outcomes for a compound statement involving P and/or Q. Find a statement corresponding to each of these 16 possibilities! Most of your statements will depend on both P and Q, but some will only depend on one or the other.

You will need one final connector: the exclusive or P \oplus Q which is true when exactly one of P and Q is true.
 egin{array}{c|c||c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} P & Q & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & & \ \hline T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T&F&F&F&F&F&F&F&F\ T&F&T&T&T&T&F&F&F&F&T&T&T&T&F&F&F&F\ F&T&T&T&F&F&T&T&F&F&T&T&F&F&T&T&F&F\ F&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F \end{array}
I'll split this into two tables for readability. We have
 egin{array}{c|c||c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} P & Q & P \vee 
eg P & P \vee Q & P \vee 
eg Q & P & 
eg P \vee Q & Q & P \Leftrightarrow Q & P \wedge 
eg Q \ \hline T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T&T\ T&F&T&T&T&T&F&F&F&F\ F&T&T&T&F&F&T&T&F&F\ F&F&T&F&T&F&T&F&T&F \end{array}
and
 egin{array}{c|c||c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} P & Q & P \wedge 
eg P & P \oplus Q & 
eg Q & P \wedge 
eg Q &

Hopefully, you noticed that there is an "anti-symmetry" to this table. The first column is the negation of the last column. The second column is the negation of the second-to-last column, and so on! So you can negate the kth statement k to find the (17-k)th statement.

In this problem, we will see that the order of our quantifiers matters
Consider the statement
\exists y \in \mathbb{R}, \forall x \in \mathbb{R}, x = y^3.
Restate the above in plain English (as well as you can). Is this statement true or false?
The statement is: "There exists a y \in \R, such that for all x \in \R, we have x=y^3."
This is false since this statement says that there is a single number y that works for every x simultaneously.
Now consider the statement
\forall y \in \mathbb{R}, \exists x \in \mathbb{R}, x = y^3.
Restate the above in plain English (as well as you can). Is this statement true or false?
The statement is: "For each y \in \R, there exists an x \in \R, such that x=y^3."
This statement is true. This time, the choice of x depends on the given y. In particular, we take x = \sqrt[3]{y}.
Here is a mathematical definition for a bounded set.

"A set S \subset \mathbb{R} is bounded if there is an M \in \mathbb{R} such that |x| \leq M for all x \in S. A set is unbounded if no such M exists."
Rewrite the definition of bounded only using mathematical symbols and quantifiers.
\[ \exists M \in \R, \forall x \in S, |x| \leq M. \]
The definition of unbounded is the negation of your statement in part (a). Write an equivalent statement that does not use a negation sign. Then rewrite that statement in plain English.
\[ \forall M \in \R, \exists x \in S, |x| > M. \] For every M \in \R, there exists an x \in S such that |x| > M.
